description: Pittsburgh was founded in 1758 at the confluence of the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, where the Ohio River begins. It was originally a strategic military outpost during the French and Indian War.
The city was named after British statesman William Pitt, the Elder, who was Prime Minister during the French and Indian War.
In 1859, Edwin Drake drilled the world’s first successful oil well in Titusville, Pennsylvania, sparking the U.S. oil boom and fueling Pittsburgh’s industrial rise.
Pittsburgh became known as the 'Steel City' in the late 19th century, due to its booming steel industry, which produced over half of the country’s steel during its peak in the 1940s.
One of the most influential African American newspapers in the U.S., *The Pittsburgh Courier*, was founded in 1907 and played a major role in the civil rights movement.
Before Fort Pitt, the French built Fort Duquesne at the confluence of the rivers in 1754, which was captured by the British in 1758 and renamed Fort Pitt.
The Pittsburgh Steelers and Cleveland Browns have one of the most intense and long-standing rivalries in the NFL, fueled by Pittsburgh’s steel heritage and Ohio’s industrial dominance.
KDKA, Pittsburgh’s radio station, made history in 1920 by broadcasting the first commercial radio broadcast in the world, announcing the results of the Harding-Cox presidential election.
Pittsburgh is the birthplace of Pop Art icon Andy Warhol. His museum, The Andy Warhol Museum, located in Pittsburgh, houses the largest collection of Warhol’s artwork.
Carnegie Mellon University, founded in 1900 by industrialist Andrew Carnegie, is a world leader in robotics, computer science, and artificial intelligence.
The Pittsburgh Pirates won their first World Series in 1909, defeating the Detroit Tigers in seven games.
Pittsburgh is one of the greenest cities in the U.S. It has over 160 parks, including the expansive Schenley Park and Frick Park, making it one of the top cities for outdoor activities.
The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, founded in 1909, has gained worldwide acclaim and is considered one of the top orchestras in the United States.
Pittsburgh is unique for its location at the confluence of three rivers: the Allegheny, Monongahela, and Ohio. The 'Three Rivers' are a significant part of the city’s identity and history.
In the 1970s, Pittsburgh’s steel mills began to close down due to foreign competition and automation, leading to the city’s 'Rust Belt' status. This catalyzed a major economic transformation.
Pittsburgh has 446 bridges, the most of any city in the U.S., and is often referred to as the 'City of Bridges.' This is due to its unique topography with many rivers and valleys.
The first ATM in the U.S. was installed at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh in 1969, revolutionizing banking worldwide.
Pittsburgh is near Seven Springs Mountain Resort, which opened in 1937 as the first commercial ski resort on the East Coast.
One of the most famous labor strikes in U.S. history occurred at the Homestead Steel Works in Pittsburgh. The strike was violently suppressed, leading to a major turning point in labor history.
Pittsburgh was the first U.S. city to install a fully electric streetcar system, which was introduced in 1889 and was a major advancement in urban transportation at the time.
The Duquesne Incline, a historic cable car railway that opened in 1877, still operates today, offering panoramic views of Pittsburgh from Mount Washington.
Pittsburgh’s famous Primanti Brothers restaurant was established in 1933 and is known for its iconic sandwiches topped with coleslaw and French fries.
The first Ferris wheel was created for the 1893 Chicago World’s Fair, but its inventor, George Ferris, was born in Pittsburgh in 1859.
Heinz ketchup, one of the world’s most recognized condiments, was first produced in Pittsburgh by the H.J. Heinz Company in 1876.
The Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh houses one of the most extensive dinosaur collections in the world, including the famous Diplodocus carnegii skeleton.
The Point State Park fountain, located at the tip of Pittsburgh’s 'Golden Triangle,' marks the spot where the three rivers meet and sprays water 150 feet into the air.
Pittsburgh is home to the first polio vaccine, developed by Dr. Jonas Salk and his team at the University of Pittsburgh in 1955.
The Monongahela Incline, built in 1870, is the oldest continuously operating funicular in the United States.
Pittsburgh is the birthplace of 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood,' the beloved children’s TV show hosted by Fred Rogers, who grew up in nearby Latrobe.
The city hosted the world’s first commercial nuclear power plant, the Shippingport Atomic Power Station, which began operating in 1958.
In 1921, the Pittsburgh Pirates played the first-ever Major League Baseball game broadcast live on the radio.
Pittsburgh was once nicknamed 'The Smoky City' due to its heavy industrial pollution during the early 20th century, but it underwent significant environmental cleanup in the 1940s.
The Cathedral of Learning at the University of Pittsburgh is the second-tallest university building in the world and a key landmark in the city.
Andrew Carnegie opened the nation’s first modern public library system in Pittsburgh in 1895, including a music hall and museum.
The Pittsburgh Zoo, established in 1898, is one of only six major zoo and aquarium combinations in the United States.
Pittsburgh was a major hub for the Underground Railroad, with many safe houses providing refuge for enslaved people seeking freedom.
The city’s Hill District was a vibrant cultural and jazz hub during the 1930s and 1940s, attracting legends like Duke Ellington and Ella Fitzgerald.
Pittsburgh is home to PNC Park, considered one of the most beautiful baseball stadiums in the U.S., offering stunning views of the city’s skyline.
The world’s first retractable dome stadium, the Civic Arena (later renamed Mellon Arena), opened in Pittsburgh in 1961.
Pittsburgh’s economy has shifted from manufacturing to technology and healthcare, with companies like Google, Uber, and Apple establishing a presence in the city.
